awd_titl_txt: WERF: Enhanced evaluation of the removal of contaminants of emerging concern in decentralized water reuse systems by non-targeted analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
PI: Natalie Mladenov
Proposal ID: 1705901 

The wastewater infrastructure in the United States and many developed countries is largely centralized and many systems are reaching the end of their design life. As an alternative to replacing thousands of miles of failing sewer pipe, decentralized wastewater treatment systems (DEWATS) coupled with membrane filtration and other advanced treatment technologies can meet water supply needs at the community-level. One important challenge in water reuse and recycling systems is the persistence of multiple types of contaminants, including contaminants of emerging concern (CECs) such as pharmaceutically active compounds that potentially number in the thousands and have frequently been detected in wastewater effluent and receiving waters. The contaminants and their potential byproducts generated during the treatment process pose an unclear risk to human health, and the mechanisms by which these chemicals are removed or transformed in DEWATS are key issues this project seeks to address. This research will employ a systematic non-targeted analytical approach to comprehensively identify both known and unexpected contaminants and byproducts in lab-scale membrane treatment systems. This project will also advance education and diversity through development of a Water Reuse Demo and Competition activity to convey themes dealing with water scarcity and reuse to middle school girls in the all-female We Are STEM Enrichment Program at San Diego State University. 

DEWATS that utilize aerobic and anaerobic membrane bioreactor technology (MBR and AnMBR, respectively), especially if coupled to additional polishing steps, have the potential to provide treatment at levels comparable to or better than conventional centralized treatment plants and will have a role in augmenting non-potable and potable water supplies. A key to the implementation of membrane reactors in DEWATS is ensuring that these systems meet current water quality standards and offer superior treatment for multiple classes of contaminants, including CECs that are detected in treated waters and the environment. For anaerobic treatment via DEWATS, the current understanding of the fate of contaminants, which has been developed around conventional large-scale aerobic treatment systems, is incomplete, and research on this front is needed to advance the use of anaerobic systems. There is a diversity of parent compounds as well as metabolites of unknown toxicity that are formed during MBR and AnMBR treatment. The goals of this research are to 1) evaluate the removal and transformation mechanisms for contaminants in aerobic and anaerobic membrane bioreactor systems and 2) enhance the identification of parent compounds as well as byproducts in MBR and AnMBR systems.  This research will employ a non-targeted analysis based on gas chromatography coupled to time-of-flight mass spectrometry (GC×GC/TOF-MS) in order to comprehensively identify both known and unknown chemicals and their bio-transformation and photo-transformation products. The research will also investigate how photolysis, which is critical in pond or wetland treatment systems that tend to follow anaerobic treatment, contributes to chemical removal and transformation. The impact of this work will be far reaching for the water reuse field because this more exhaustive evaluation of chemicals and their transformation in small-scale membrane treatment systems will inform the growing decentralized movement in the US and abroad.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
One important challenge in wastewater treatment and water reuse systems is the persistence of contaminants of emerging concern (CECs) such as pharmaceutically active compounds that potentially number in the thousands and have frequently been detected in wastewater effluent and receiving waters. While wastewater treatment plants were not intended for the removal of CECs, some compounds are attenuated through the treatment train. The persistence and removal of contaminants and the generation of byproducts during anaerobic and aerobic treatment processes and via photochemical reactions were key questions addressed by this research. Also, this research sought to probe the physical and chemical properties of compounds that may promote their removal or transformation in decentralized and centralized wastewater treatment systems. Given that wastewater comprises many compounds that are not yet known, this research employed a systematic non-targeted chemical analysis (NTA) to comprehensively identify both known and unexpected contaminants and byproducts in lab-scale and real-world treatment systems.

In Phase I, we sampled influent and effluent of centralized and decentralized wastewater treatment plants in the US and South Africa. Although centralized treatment systems that utilize aerobic biological processes were expected to produce the greatest compound removal, our results showed that decentralized wastewater treatment using an anaerobic baffled reactor coupled to constructed wetlands resulted in similar rates of CEC removal (Figure 1). The NTA approach further identified toxic compounds and compounds with environmental and human health hazards that persisted through all treatment trains, including compounds that had not been previously reported in the literature. There was no single physical or chemical property linked significantly to persistence or removal, indicating that in real-world systems, removal mechanisms for CECs are complex and multi-faceted.

In Phase II, we further explored the influence of aerobic and anaerobic biological processes on CEC removal by treating real wastewater with parallel aerobic and anaerobic membrane bioreactors (AeMBR and AnMBR) at the laboratory scale. Greater CEC removal was achieved with the AeMBR, but the AeMBR also had slightly higher production of transformation products than the AnMBR (Figure 2). Furthermore, the AeMBR generated sludge on a daily basis, whereas sludge generation in the AnMBR was almost negligible. Statistical analyses also confirmed that no set of physical or chemical characteristics were significantly related to compound removal or persistence. Suspect screening analysis using GCxGC/TOF-MS, which resulted in the tentative identification of 351 TOrCs, proved to be a powerful approach for uncovering new compounds that have not previously been reported in wastewater, including many fragrances and personal care products.

Phase III explored the influence of sunlight and microbes on the degradation of CECs in treated effluent discharged to the environment. Real secondary wastewater effluent obtained from a local wastewater treatment plant was exposed in a 2x2 factorial experiment to sunlight and dark conditions, in the presence and absence of native microorganisms. Suspect screening analysis using GCxGC/TOF-MS revealed that sunlight had the greatest effect on CEC removal and also generated the highest number of transformation products (Figure 3). The presence or absence of microbes did not have a significant influence on the number of compounds removed in simulated sunlight conditions. Under dark conditions, very few compounds were removed. In agreement with the results of Phases I and II, there were no statistically significant relationships between physical or chemical characteristics leading to greater compound removal. 

This project resulted in the publication of several peer-reviewed journal articles that list all persistent, removed, and transformed compounds classified with our tentative identification process. The NTA approach uncovered new compounds found in personal care and cleaning products and fragrances as well as a distressing number of plastic-derived compounds; these data are important for informing future monitoring programs.

The project also supported a large number of undergraduate and graduate students, including 7 students from Native American and Latinx groups who are under-represented in science and engineering. The project advanced K-12 education by promoting awareness of water treatment and reuse, water quality issues, and careers in the environmental engineering and public health fields through SDSU student-led Clean Water Challenge activities (Figure 4), made possible with assistance from the MESA Program and local tribal education and outreach programs. Informal surveys revealed that, after the outreach activity, K-12 participants had significantly greater awareness of chemicals in water and wastewater and the different technologies available to treatment them (Figure 4).

 


Last Modified: 12/01/2023
Modified by: Natalie Mladenov
